title: Linux Security Monitoring & Logging
subtitle: Signal-rich telemetry for defenders and responders
learning_objectives: Configure auditd and journald for high fidelity security telemetry
Normalise Linux logs for SIEM ingestion and correlation
Detect suspicious activity using open source rules and baseline tuning
Balance retention, cost, and compliance for log storage
Integrate Linux telemetry into DFIR and threat hunting workflows
Harden logging infrastructure against adversarial tampering

content_blocks.title: Treat Telemetry as a Product

content.text: Logs are not a by-product—they are the product defenders consume. Approach every configuration change with user empathy: will this signal help the responder make a faster, better decision?

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Craft logs so they are immediately useful to analysts.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: High-performing SOCs run telemetry engineering as a product team.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: What log source currently frustrates your defenders the most?

content_blocks.title: Telemetry Pillars

content.text:
## Capture, Normalise, Operationalise
- **Capture** – auditd, journald, FIM, and network sensors provide raw signal.
- **Normalise** – translate into schemas (ECS/Sigma) and enrich with context.
- **Operationalise** – build detections, dashboards, and playbooks.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Collect, standardise, and use the data—skip any step and value drops.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Telemetry teams use this framing when negotiating roadmap priorities.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which pillar is weakest in your current environment?

content_blocks.title: LOGS Checklist

content.text:
### L.O.G.S.
- **L**ock down collectors
- **O**ptimise for context (user, host, process)
- **G**uard against tampering (remote storage, immutability)
- **S**hare dashboards and detections with responders

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Use LOGS to sanity-check every pipeline.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Security architects apply similar checklists before promoting configs to production.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which LOGS element is missing from your current setup?

content_blocks.title: Field Example: MSSP Detection Uplift

content.text: A managed security provider standardised audit rules across 2,000 Linux servers, fed enriched events into their detection platform, and reduced investigation time by 40%. They caught a coin-mining campaign that had previously evaded controls.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Consistent telemetry and enrichment unlock faster detection.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Adapted from an MSSP case study presented at a SANS summit.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: What is the first standard you will apply across your fleet?

content_blocks.title: Build a Logging Blueprint

content.text:
1. Draft auditd rules covering credential changes, process execution, and network sockets.
2. Plan log forwarding to your SIEM, including fail-open behaviour and backlog handling.
3. Identify dashboards or alerts that operationalise the telemetry.
4. Capture the blueprint in your runbook and assign owners.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Design your telemetry pipeline on paper before altering production.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Blueprint exercises help SOCs justify tooling investments.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which stakeholders must approve this blueprint?

content_blocks.title: Teach Back the Telemetry

content.text:
### Reflect & Teach
- Explain your blueprint to a responder, emphasising LOGS checkpoints.
- List two detections you will build once telemetry is online.
- Identify one safeguard that keeps attackers from tampering with logs.

content_blocks.simplified_explanation: Teaching ensures your telemetry plan is understandable and actionable.
content_blocks.real_world_connection: Telemetry engineers share these briefings during sprint reviews.
content_blocks.reflection_prompt: Which responder will you partner with for feedback?

post_assessment.question: Why normalise Linux logs before sending them to a SIEM?
options: To make correlation and detection rules consistent
post_assessment.explanation: Normalised logs allow reusable detection logic and faster triage.

post_assessment.question: Which component records kernel-level events for security monitoring?
post_assessment.explanation: Auditd captures system calls and kernel events necessary for deep visibility.

post_assessment.question: Why should logging infrastructure be hardened?
options: Attackers target logs to cover tracks; protecting them preserves evidence
post_assessment.explanation: Tamper-resistant logging ensures defenders can trust their telemetry.
